title: How Not to Get Tricked by “Support” Scammers in Crypto (and What to Do If You Already Slipped Up)
keyQuestions: How do I know this support account is real?
Why do scammers reply faster than real support?
Will real support ever ask for my seed phrase or private key?
How do I verify an official support channel?
What screenshots and logs are safe to share?
What should I do if I already shared something sensitive?
quickSteps: Pause first and refuse urgency: no new links, installs, screenshares, or “verification” steps.
Verify the support channel from the official website (bookmark or typed domain), not from DMs or ads.
Cross-check identity in two official places (website + app help menu or older official pinned post).
Share only safe data: TXID, network, time, order ID, and redacted errors—never recovery words or keys.
If anything sensitive leaked, treat it as compromised and migrate funds to a new wallet on a clean device.
riskNotes: Fast replies and urgency are not credibility signals; they are common manipulation tools.
Legitimate support will never ask for seed phrases, private keys, 2FA codes, or remote access.
Look-alike domains and handles often differ by one character, an extra word, or a different TLD.
Wallet logs and screenshots can leak sensitive metadata; redact or avoid sharing them unless you know what they contain.
If recovery words were shared, there is no safe “fix” other than moving funds to a new seed phrase.
